Tuning the basicity of Cu-based mixed oxide catalysts towards the efficient conversion of glycerol to glycerol carbonate Marimuthu Manikandan a Marimuthu Prabu b S.K. Ashok Kumar a Palanivelu Sangeetha a ⁎ Rajagopalan Vijayaraghavan a a Department of Chemistry, School of Advanced Sciences, VIT, Vellore, 632014, India Department of Chemistry School of Advanced Sciences VIT Vellore 632014 India b Catalysis & Inorganic Chemistry Division, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory, Dr. Homi Bhabha Road, Pune, 411 008, India Catalysis & Inorganic Chemistry Division CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory Dr. Homi Bhabha Road Pune 411 008 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A series of efficient and robust Cu based mixed oxides were synthesized by a simple co-precipitation method and utilized for the production of glycerol carbonate (GC) via transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC). The synthesized materials were characterized using XRD, UV–vis spectroscopy, SEM, TEM, N2 sorption, CO2-TPD, and XPS. The addition of Cu on Mg/Al mixed oxides exhibits significant changes in its physicochemical properties and catalytic activity. The obtained mixed oxides showed remarkably high transesterification activity towards the efficient conversion of glycerol to GC under economical reaction conditions without using any solvent. Among all the catalysts employed, highest catalytic activity was observed over MAC-0.6 catalyst with glycerol conversion of 96.4% and GC yield of 91.2%. The improved catalytic performance was observed mainly due to the optimized catalyst molar ratio and strong surface basicity. The strong surface basic sites were greatly attributed to the incorporation of Cu2+ cations in the MgAl (O) periclase that efficiently catalyzed the transesterification of glycerol with DMC. Furthermore, the reported catalyst was robust and could be recycled for more than five times without any significant loss in its catalytic activity. Keywords Copper Mixed oxides Transesterification Glycerol Glycerol carbonate 1 Introduction The utilization of renewable sources for the fine chemical synthesis became revolutionary research area in the perspective of both industry and academia [1]. Owing to the increasing day-by-day demand for renewable biofuels, biodiesel production has received significant attention, as it is a viable alternative to non-renewable fossil fuels as well as other sustainable biofuels [2]. Glycerol, a globally traded commodity chemical which is generated as an undesired side product during the production of biodiesel. Also, the available literatures conferred, 10% of waste glycerol is assigned during every ton of biodiesel production by transesterification of oils with methanol [2]. The utilization of surplus waste glycerol as a low-cost platform molecule stands for a promising substrate to procure value-added chemicals from renewable raw materials [3–5]. Recent research has been mainly centered on the development of modern chemical pathways for the efficient conversion of glycerol to value-added chemicals. Glycerol carbonate (GC) is one of the crucial glycerol derivatives that attract major scientific and industrial interest owing to its distinct physical, chemical properties and uses [6]. Moreover, GC has diverse applications such as a solvent, chemical intermediate, polycarbonates synthesis, glycidol-based polymers, and surfactants etc., [6,7]. Diverse synthesis methodologies have been developed to upgrade a large amount of waste glycerol into GC over the past few decades. Traditionally, GC has been synthesized via the carbonylation of glycerol with carbon monoxide or phosgene [7], but this route has been deserted due to their toxicity and unsafe reactants. Besides, the GC production from glycerol with CO and CO2 also demonstrated, however, these routes suffer from low GC yield and exorbitant operation cost [8–10]. Additionally, the carbonylation synthesis route has severe environmental concerns due to the use of CO, CO2 and the intrinsic crisis to handle it securely both at the laboratory and industrial scale. The production of GC from glycerol and urea also another method for the synthesis of GC, however, the high GC yield can be achieved only the continuous removal of the produced ammonia gas while the reaction progress [11]. Importantly, the transcarbonation with various carbonates process provides a facile approach for GC synthesis owing to the ease of operation and mild reaction conditions [12–16]. Climent et al. reported basic oxides and mixed oxides catalyzed transesterification of ethylene carbonate with glycerol and achieved 98% of GC yield [17]. Among the employed catalytic pathways, the transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is the most promising route for the production of GC as it is much safer and greener over other methods [15]. Despite various catalyst systems have been explored towards GC synthesis, the requirement for an efficient, single step, economic and environmentally benign catalyst for sustainable GC production still remains. The extensive literature studies proved that the strong surface basic sites rather than the moderate and weak basic sites can efficiently catalyze the transesterification of glycerol with DMC [12]. In recent years, several reports on the synthesis of GC from glycerol using various heterogeneous base catalysts, such as KF-hydroxyapatite composites [13], CaO [18], CaO-La2O3 [19], ZnO/La2O3 [20] and K2CO3-MgO [21], have been accounted. However, in the future perspective of sustainable heterogeneous catalysts, there are still some issues required to be addressed, such as poor GC yield, solvent-free conditions, low reaction temperature and economical operating cost. Hence, the immense attention to a modern approach needs to be developed with the aim of achieving excellent GC production with robust catalyst stability at mild reaction conditions. Transition metal incorporated Mg/Al mixed oxides in the form of layered double hydroxide (LDH) type materials has attracted growing attention in the area of heterogeneous catalysis. The layered Mg/Al-based mixed oxides has many applications in various research fields owing to their atomic level distribution of transition metal cations in the brucite layered structure and the capability to intercalate various interlayer anions [22–25]. Furthermore, LDH derived mixed oxides displays a great potential as a precursor and support to develop a promising catalytic material as it assists high dispersion and firm thermal stability to afford eminent catalytic performance and reusability [24]. One of the most pertinent properties of layered mixed oxides is that they behave as an excellent solid base material. Due to its distinct basic nature, Mg/Al mixed oxide type materials have been extensively explored as heterogeneous solid base catalysts for different organic transformations, such as hydrogenation, transesterification, alkylation and Aldol condensation [25–29]. Salomão et al. reported that the origin of the basic properties of these materials is directly associated with their chemical composition, nature of intercalated ions, structure and thermal activation conditions [30]. The basic sites can be mainly attributed due to the presence of interlayer OH− groups and surface O2− species, which can be assigned as Brønsted and Lewis type basic sites, respectively [17,31]. Additionally, presence of the surface hydroxyl groups favors as charge compensation anions and strongly improve the accessibility of the Brønsted-type basic sites [17,31], whereas, the presence of surface O2- species upon calcination leads to the formation of surface Lewis basic sites [17,23]. Being basic in nature, mixed oxide based materials has been extensively utilized for the GC synthesis in recent years. Malyaadri et al. achieved an appreciable yield of GC over Mg/Al/Zr oxides [2]. Parameswaram et al. showed the Mg/Zr/Sr based mixed oxides are highly active for the production of GC through the transesterification of glycerol with DMC [14]. Takagaki et al. accomplished tunable basic site density of calcined LDHs by altering the Mg/Al ratio and calcination temperature and found that the transesterification activity primarily correlated with surface basic site density [32]. Recently, Liu et al. demonstrated the basicity of Mg/Al mixed oxides can be tuned by the addition of transition metal ions and emphasized that the strong surface basicity has high influence on GC yield [23]. However, an extensive study on the influence of individual metal incorporation on Mg/Al based mixed oxides in favour of glycerol conversion is seldom reported and we considered it is worth investigating. Based on the exhaustive analysis of the reported literature and patents, efforts were made towards achieving a single step conversion of glycerol to GC employing a room temperature synthesized Cu-based mixed oxides as an efficient heterogeneous base catalyst. Herein, the synergistic influence of combining Cu loading on the physicochemical properties and catalytic performance of Mg/Al mixed oxide has been systematically investigated. Moreover, the diverse reaction parameters were optimized and correlated to the GC yield. The appreciable GC yield for more than 91% can be achieved through the fine-tuned surface basicity and optimized reaction conditions. The obtained results clearly indicate the basicity optimized Cu-based mixed oxides have been found to be a promising catalyst towards the highly efficient conversion of glycerol to GC under affordable reaction conditions with robust performance. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of Cu-based mixed oxide catalysts The Cu-based mixed oxide catalysts were synthesized by conventional co-precipitation method at room temperature. All chemicals purchased from S D Fine-Chem Limited were directly used without further purification. In a typical synthesis, a 0.25 M of metal precursor solution A was prepared by dissolving Mg (NO3)2. 6H2O, Al (NO3)3. 9H2O and Cu (NO3)2. 3H2O in 100 ml of double distilled water. Precipitating base solution B was prepared by dissolving a 0.5 M of NaOH and 0.25 M of Na2CO3 in 100 ml of double distilled water. The co-precipitation has been done by dropwise addition of metal precursor solution A and base solution B simultaneously into a beaker with gentle stirring. The pH was maintained at 9.5 ± 0.2 and the solution was further stirred for an hour, subsequently, the slurry was allowed for aging at room temperature for 12 h. The obtained precipitate was washed thoroughly with double distilled water to remove the surplus base. Then, the sample was dried in a hot air oven for 12 h at 110 °C. Finally, the obtained sample was calcined at 450 °C for 6 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1. For the systematic study, a series of Cu-based mixed oxides Mg3-xAl1Cux (with the ratio of Mg2+:Al3+ cations is 3:1) was prepared with a various molar ratio of Cu (x = 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8) and denoted as MAC-0.2, MAC-0.4, MAC-0.6 and MAC-0.8, where MAC stands for magnesium, aluminium and copper, respectively. A Cu-free catalyst was synthesized by using the same procedure without adding copper precursor and the obtained sample is denoted as MgAl (O). In addition, 5–20 wt% of Cu loaded on MgAl (O) were synthesized by impregnation method and the calcined sample denoted as x-wt% Cu/MgAl(O), where x stands for the Cu loading in wt%. 2.2 Characterization techniques X-ray diffraction (XRD) data of synthesized powder samples were collected from D8 advance BRUKER (Germany) in the 2θ range between 05°-90°. The Bragg equation is applied to determine the interlayer distance (d) nλ = 2d sin θ, where λ = 0.154 nm. UV–vis spectra of the samples were recorded using JASCO-V670 spectrophotometer. The morphology of the sample was observed using Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with energy dispersive x-ray analyzer (SEM-EDX) from FEI Nova Nano SEM 450 FE-SEM. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) micrographs of all the materials were recorded by a FEI TECNAI F20 electron microscope operating at 200 kV. The TEM sample was prepared using 2-propanol as a solvent with standard procedure. The copper wt% present in the calcined samples was quantified by Inductively Coupled Plasma-Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES, Spectro Arcos, FHS-12) analysis. CO2-Temperature Programmed Desorption (CO2-TPD) studies were carried out in Micrometrics 2920 instrument. Nearly 50 mg of powder sample was loaded in “U” shaped quartz tube for CO2-TPD analysis. The sample was pre-treated from room temperature to 450 °C (5 °C/min ramping) using Helium as a carrier gas. For analysis, 10% CO2 in Helium gas mixture was allowed to adsorb on the sample surface and allowed to desorb in a temperature range from room temperature to 900 °C (10 °C /min ramping). The surface area and pore characteristics of the calcined materials were determined by N2 sorption analysis at −196 °C using Quantachrome Instruments version 5.0. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation was applied to calculate the surface area of the calcined samples from the adsorption branch. Pore size and pore volume measurements are collected from Barret, Joyner, and Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution analysis. Magnesium, copper and oxygen core levels were analyzed with X-Ray Photo Spectrometer from Thermo Fisher Scientific Instruments UK using Al Kα anode (1486.6 eV). 2.3 Catalytic activity test Transesterification of glycerol to GC was carried out in the liquid phase reaction under atmospheric pressure. In a typical batch experiment, 2 g of glycerol, 9.78 g of DMC and 300 mg of catalyst were placed in a 100 ml round bottom flask equipped with a condenser and kept at constant stirring using magnetic stirrer. Subsequently, the desired reaction temperature was achieved by heating the system. The reaction progress was monitored by collecting the samples at regular intervals, cooled and analyzed using High-Pressure Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) by separating the products on an Organic acid H+ (8%) column with 0.005 M sulphuric acid as the mobile phase. The products were identified by the GC–MS analysis. The glycerol conversion, GC selectivity and yield were quantified by using the following equations: 3 Results and discussion 3.1 X-ray diffraction X-ray diffraction patterns of the as-synthesized samples are shown in Fig. 1 . All samples exhibit symmetrical reflections at 11.5°, 23.2°, 60.5° and 61.8° assigned to the (0 0 3), (0 0 6) and (0 0 9) planes, whereas asymmetric reflections at 34.6°, 38.9° and 46.3° assigned to the (0 1 5) (0 1 8), (1 1 0) and (0 1 3) planes. From the diffractogram of the as-synthesized Cu-based mixed oxides, the resemblance in the diffraction pattern consistent with the characteristic patterns for LDH structure (JCPDS no. 41-1428) demonstrating the brucite-like layered mixed oxides were successfully fabricated [33]. The interlayer distance measured from the reflection at 2θ = 11.4° (d003) is 0.76 nm, which is similar to the value reported by Li et al., consistent with the well-known spacing for the interlayer CO3 2− anions [34]. The XRD patterns suggest no peak attributable to CuO is present, which is evidenced that the CuO is highly dispersed in the layered structure. The absence of CuO phases also adverts that the Mg2+ cations are isomorphically substituted by Cu2+ cations in the brucite layers. In Fig. 2 , XRD pattern of the calcined Cu-based samples are shown. The patterns clearly show the disintegration of the layered structure and the formation of mixed oxides due to the heat treatment. After the thermal treatment at 450 °C, the layered structure is completely disappeared and a diffuse diffraction pattern of MgAl (O) periclase (JCPDS no. 4-829), with peaks (2θ = 43.2° and 62.3°) predominantly appeared [25]. Furthermore, the absence of the distinct diffractions for copper oxides in the entire pattern suggests the presence of small CuO nanoparticles or amorphous CuO species. However, at the highest molar ratio of copper (MAC-0.8) upon calcination, a weak reflection and a slight peak broadening at 2θ = 35.5° indicate that the formation of CuO. This suggests that the dispersion of copper is mainly relies on the Cu loadings and the good dispersion can be observed up to MAC-0.6. Further copper loading (MAC-0.8) lead to the agglomeration of Cu species on the layered structure, thus it shows the corresponding CuO peaks in the XRD patterns. The XRD pattern of as-synthesised and a calcined sample of 5–20 wt% of Cu/MgAl (O) is given in the Electronic Supplementary information (ESI) Fig. S1 for the comparison. The XRD pattern of the as-synthesised impregnated samples does not show similar reflection after 10 wt% of Cu loading that inconsistent to the co-precipitated sample, suggests that the layered structure is altered due to impregnation. On the other hand, calcined samples show increase in intensity of reflections with increasing Cu loading (2θ = 35.6°, 38.8° and 48.8°) that corresponds to the CuO which further leads to the formation of large crystallites after thermal treatment. 3.2 Textural properties The textural properties of Cu-based mixed oxides were examined by N2 sorption studies and the corresponding results are given in Table 1 . The BET surface area of pristine MgAl (O) mixed oxide is 147.6 m2/g and the samples consist of the various Cu molar ratio show considerable variation in the surface area. Notably, the sample MAC-0.6 shows a substantial increment in the surface area is about 165.2 m2/g as well as large pore size (4.3 nm). An increase in the surface area by addition of copper loadings might be attributable to the new surface adsorption sites generation originated from the high Cu dispersion along with the enhancement of pore characteristics. Furthermore, a small decrease in the surface area for the MAC-0.8 sample can be ascribed to the agglomeration of CuO on the mixed oxide structure and also higher copper loadings prone to pore blockage as evidenced from the reported literatures [35]. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distribution for calcined samples are shown in Fig. 3 . All Cu-based mixed oxides were presented typical plots that are corresponding to type IV isotherm with H3 hysteresis loops [25]. The pore size distribution of the calcined samples demonstrates that the pores are uniformly ranged from 1 to15 nm. From the N2 sorption studies, it can be concluded that the MAC-0.6 sample shows distinct behavior with highest textural properties among all the prepared materials ascribed to the appropriate Cu molar ratio in the periclase structure. Furthermore, the Cu-based mixed oxides synthesized by impregnated method exhibited considerably low surface area and pore characteristics (Table. S1) as compared to co-precipitation method. The diminishing in textural properties resulting from the impregnation method might be due to the lack of uniform distribution of active species on the support surface. This confirms that the co-precipitation method provides good textural properties over the impregnated catalyst which might be due to the atomic level dispersion of Cu species on layered structure. 3.3 Scanning electron microscopy The surface morphology of Cu based mixed oxides were observed by SEM and the corresponding images are shown in Fig. 4 . The micrographs demonstrate a flower-like morphology of parent layered structure as reported in the literature [36], no change in morphology was observed even after Cu incorporation up to MAC-0.6 sample. The micrographs also demonstrate the uniform dispersion of CuO species on periclase structure, which is consistent with the XRD analysis. Moreover, no agglomeration was observed for MAC-0.6 sample evidenced that the successful incorporation of CuO particles on periclase with strong surface synergism. The elemental mapping (Fig. 4f–h) of the sample surface displayed a very uniform distribution of Mg, Al, Cu and O species. The analyzed EDAX (Fig. 4i) shows the presence of Mg, Al, Cu and O species and the obtained Cu content is 15.2%, which is very close to the ICP-OES results and the stoichiometric amount of precursors taken for the synthesis. The presence of Cu species in the as-synthesized catalysts is further confirmed by UV–vis spectroscopy (ESI, Fig. S2), the UV–vis absorbance increases as the relative quantity of copper increases in the sample, which corroborates that the absorbance behavior of copper oxides with increasing copper content even in the layered structure [37,38]. 3.4 Transmission electron microscopy Fig. 5 depicts the TEM micrographs of the calcined MAC-0.6 sample. The micrographs (Fig. 5a–b) clearly demonstrate assemblies of thin plate-like nanoparticles which are derived from the nucleation at the initial crystallization stage of the layered structure [32]. No hexagonal dimension was observed in the whole sample substantiated the layered structure was converted to mixed oxides after calcination treatment [25]. Moreover, the high magnification micrograph (Fig. 5c) shows the uniform plate-like morphology in the complete system. Notably, no discrete Cu species were observed the entire analysis, emphasized that the highly dispersed nature of copper oxides. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 5d) with clearly defined electron diffraction spots substantiates the semi-crystalline nature of mixed oxides. The XRD patterns also corroborated that the synthesized mixed oxides exhibited layered structure and had low crystallinity as consistent with the TEM results. 3.5 CO2-TPD analysis The CO2-TPD analysis was carried out to measure the surface basic strength distribution of the Cu-based mixed oxides. Fig. 6 shows representative profiles of CO2 desorption for all mixed oxide samples. As shown in the figure, the pristine MgAl (O) sample shows a broad desorption peak centered at 498 °C, whereas MAC-0.2 and MAC-0.4 samples exhibit two CO2 desorption peaks, including adsorption at weak basic sites located at around 200 °C and strong basic sites located around 450–650 °C. Interestingly, a high-temperature desorption peak appeared for MAC-0.6 and MAC-0.8 samples are attributed to the generation of very strong basic sites. Notably, the appearance of sharp desorption at 600 °C for MAC-0.4 sample specifies the generation of strong basic sites. The origin of weak and strong basic sites in Mg/Al based mixed oxides are mainly attributable to the adsorption of CO2 at the surface Brönsted and Lewis basic sites, which are originated to the presence of OH− groups and O2− ions, respectively [17,23]. Apparently, the basic strength distribution was calculated for all samples and listed in Table 1. Both total and strong basic sites of the samples were monotonously increased with the increment of the Cu content up to MAC-0.6 and show a slight decrease for the MAC-0.8 sample. Among all, MAC-0.6 sample exhibited the highest amount of total basic sites (0.98 mmol g−1) and strong basic sites (0.82 mmol g−1) as well. Furthermore, the strong basicity might be ascribed to the presence of an optimum amount of Cu species on MgAl (O) surface that renders strong Lewis basic sites in great amount. The similar trend was also observed form BET surface area results, which emphasizes that the enhancement in both surface area and strong basic strength was observed for samples up to MAC-0.6 might be due to the appreciable dispersion of copper oxides on periclase structure. Moreover, the impregnated 5–20 wt% of Cu/MgAl (O) samples demonstrates relatively lower basic site density (ESI, Table. S1) compared to the co-precipitated samples attributable to the formation of aggregated Cu species caused by impregnation method. 3.6 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy The more insights into the surface chemical nature of Cu species have been investigated by XPS analysis and the recorded core levels of Mg 1 s, Cu 2p and O 1 s are shown in Fig. 7 after deconvolution. Fig. 7a depicts the Mg 1 s peak located at 1302.2 eV, two major peaks observed after deconvoluted at 1302 eV and 1303 eV can be assigned Mg(OH)2 and MgO, respectively [39]. Fig. 7b shows the predominant spin-orbit peak for Cu 2p3/2 core level bind energy values at 932.9 eV and its corresponding shake-up satellite peak at 941.6 eV, which are in accordance with the literature reports [40–42]. The deconvoluted spectra clearly conferred that the presence of the predominant Cu2+ state in the sample. The observation of strong satellite peaks in Cu 2p3/2 region further confirms the presence of the Cu2+ chemical state. Furthermore, the recorded O 1 s core levels (Fig. 7c) shows two peaks at 530.6 eV and 529.1 eV corresponds to the surface OH− and O2-, respectively [43]. The deconvoluted profiles of both Mg 1 s and O 1 s core levels clearly demonstrate that the availability of OH− and O2- species, which are responsible for the surface basicity. These results strongly underpin the observations made from the CO2-TPD analysis for Brönsted and Lewis basic sites. 4 Catalytic activity for the transesterification of glycerol with DMC The following parameters have been optimized and the catalytic activity has been correlated well with the catalyst and its characterization techniques data. 4.1 Cu loading The correlation of basic site density and catalytic activity of Cu-based mixed oxide catalysts were studied towards the transesterification activity of glycerol with DMC and the obtained results are depicted in Fig. 8 . The transesterification of glycerol over Cu-based catalysts predominantly resulted in the yield of GC and a small amount of Glycidol (GD) as a side product, as shown in Scheme 1 . The formation of GC from transesterification of glycerol in the absence of any catalyst is negligible. The transesterification activity of MgAl (O) and Cu-based mixed oxides are shown in the Fig. 8 for the sake of comparison. All the Cu-based catalysts showed excellent activity towards transesterification of glycerol compared to bare MgAl (O) periclase. The MgAl (O) catalyst showed relatively less yield of GC (54%) as compared to Cu-based mixed oxide catalysts. The yield of GC increased with increasing Cu loading up to MAC-0.6 catalyst then the slight decrease in the activity was observed for the MAC-0.8 catalyst. Among the catalysts evaluated, the highest activity and TOF was observed for MAC-0.6 with 91.2% of GC yield. All catalysts render GD as a by-product owing to the decarbonylation of GC. The origin of transesterification activity observed for the Cu-based mixed oxide catalysts could be speculated from the observed physicochemical characteristics. From the rational evaluation of the characterization results, MAC-0.6 catalyst shows distinct behavior as compared with other catalysts. It can be clearly seen that MAC-0.6 has highest values of both surface area and strong basic site density (0.82 mmol g−1). The reported literature emphasized that the transesterification reaction is facilitated by surface basic sites and availability of strong Lewis basicity is responsible for the enhanced transesterification activity [44,45]. However, all Cu- based catalysts exhibit a reasonable GC yield due to the presence of an optimum amount of Lewis basic sites. The present results underpin that the strong Lewis basic sites of the Cu-based catalyst play a significant role in acquiring a high yield of GC. Furthermore, the catalytic evaluation of 5–20 wt% of Cu loaded on MgAl (O) were also studied and the results are presented in Table. S1. The catalytic performance of all impregnated catalysts are remarkably lower than that of co-precipitated catalysts. Because impregnation method caused agglomerated Cu species and restrained amount of active site deposition on the support surface while co-precipitation method render homogeneous distribution of Cu species, as evidenced from the textural evaluation results. 4.2 Reaction temperature The obtained results from the screening of various Cu-based catalysts, the MAC-0.6 catalyst is chosen for the further optimization studies, as it exhibited the excellent catalytic performance. The effect of the reaction temperature on transesterification of glycerol was investigated and the obtained results are shown in Fig. 9 . The transesterification reaction was carried out with the temperature range from 50 °C to 130 °C. As depicted in the figure, the glycerol conversion increased monotonously with the increasing reaction temperature from 50 °C to 130 °C. A glycerol conversion of 96.4% was achieved when the reaction temperature was at 90 °C and almost complete conversion noticed at 130 °C, proposed that the rise in reaction temperature led to the enhancement of the glycerol conversion. Furthermore, a gradual decrease in the GC selectivity was observed with the reaction temperature increased from 50 °C to 130 °C. A drastic decrease in the GC selectivity with increasing reaction temperature can be attributed to the consequent increase of GD selectivity. The GD formation is speculated to the decarbonylation of GC and it is more feasible at higher reaction temperatures [14]. Based on the observed results, the optimum reaction temperature is chosen at 90 °C and used for the further studies. 4.3 Glycerol to DMC mole ratio The influence of mole ratios of the reactants was evaluated and the crucial results are shown in Fig. 10 . A less glycerol conversion is observed at a lower glycerol to DMC mole ratio (1:3). A gradual increase in the conversion with an increasing mole ratio was observed and reached a maximum conversion of 96.4% at a mole ratio of 1:5 and show a slight decrease in conversion for 1:10 ratio. On the other hand, the increase in the GC yield observed up to 1:5 M ratios and a substantial decrease in the GC yield was noticed at 1:10 M ratio. This result emphasizes that the GC yield is significantly influenced by the mole ratio of the reactants. A notable observation was found in this study, the yield of GC elevated as the glycerol to DMC ratio increased, consequently the yield GD suppressed gradually. This result also indicates the high DMC concentration favored the transesterification of glycerol to yield GC instead of the GD formation through the decarbonylation of GC. Furthermore, the concentrations of DMC molecules are astringent at low glycerol to DMC ratio, proceeds towards decarbonylation of GC on catalyst surface resulting in high GD yield. 4.4 Catalyst loading The influence of catalyst concentration on the glycerol transesterification was explored and the results are shown in Fig. 10. For this study, the catalyst mass was varied from 100 to 500 mg whereas other parameters were kept constant. The conversion of glycerol was increased with an increment of catalyst concentration. Consequently, the yield of GC enhanced initially with an increase in the catalyst content. A slight decline in both conversion and GC yield was observed at a high catalyst concentration in the reaction mixture might be ascribed to the inadequate catalyst dispersion in the reaction medium. However, the gradual increment of GD selectivity with an increase in the catalyst amount was observed, corroborates that the availability of strong surface basic sites facilitates the decarbonylation after the peak of highest glycerol conversion. These results demonstrate that the yield of GC and GD is in accompanying with the high catalyst concentration performs the transesterification and decarbonylation, respectively. 4.5 Catalyst recyclability The stability of the most active MAC-0.6 catalyst is evaluated by recyclability experiments for five consecutive batch reactions under optimized reaction conditions. For the recyclability study, the catalyst was washed with distilled water and methanol after each run. From the Fig. 11 , the glycerol conversion and GC yield were decreased slightly as the increasing catalytic cycles and 88.6% of GC yield was obtained even at the 5th catalytic cycle. On the other hand, the yield of GD shows a gradual increase in as the increased catalyst cycles conferred that the favor of decarbonylation. The reported catalyst system did not show a drastic decline in its activity conferred the robustness of the Cu-based mixed oxides. To underpin the catalyst sustainability, the spent catalyst was examined by XRD and no differentiable phase change in the XRD pattern (Fig. S3, ESI) suggested that the catalyst is extremely stable even after five catalytic runs. 4.6 Plausible reaction mechanism Based on the results from our studies, a plausible mechanism can be drawn on basis of the basic site distribution over Cu-based mixed metal oxide catalysts. As illustrated in the Scheme 2 , the initial reaction proceeds through the abstraction of acidic proton from primary hydroxyl group of a glycerol molecule by the basic sites of the catalyst to produce corresponding glyceroxide anion and the conjugate acid of the base [46,47]. In the next step, the reaction between glyceroxide anion and DMC leads the methoxide anion and methyl glyceryl carbonate intermediate, consequently the reaction between the formed methoxide anion and conjugate acid from the previous step yielding methanol [19,47]. In the last step, the unstable methyl glyceryl carbonate intermediate undergoes cyclization reaction through nucleophilic attack of the oxygen from the secondary hydroxyl group on the carbonyl carbon eventually converted to GC and methanol. In general, the conventional homogeneous catalyst consists of close contact and facile proton adsorption active sites, the mass transport phenomena is nullified since the reaction proceed via a single phase. On the other hand, for the heterogeneous catalyst, transesterification reaction proceeds via biphasic system so solid base catalyst must overcome the mass transfer limitation. In this context, the glycerol molecule must diffuse from the bulk solution to the catalyst surface, so adequate base strength is imperative to the proton abstraction from the primary hydroxyl group of a glycerol molecule. Moreover, the strong surface basic strength paves more negatively charged glyceroxide anion (C3H7O3 −) and consequently, the free energy of the reaction gets lower [19]. As discussed in the CO2-TPD studies, all the samples show very good basic sites up to 1 mmol density. The in-depth analysis and correlation of the basic site density and catalytic activity imply that the catalyst containing highest strong basic sites can easily adsorb the proton from the glycerol molecule to initiate the reaction. Also, the reported mixed oxides have the appreciable surface area and pore size to overcome the diffusion and mass transport limitation. Finally, the conclusion can be drawn that the Cu-based mixed oxide catalyst with high enough strong basic sites can efficiently do the transesterification of glycerol to produce an appreciable yield of GC. 5 Conclusion In the present study, Cu-containing Mg/Al based mixed oxides were synthesized by a facile co-precipitation method with varying Cu molar ratio. The synthesized mixed oxides were found to be highly efficient for the synthesis of GC via the transesterification of glycerol with DMC. The foregoing catalyst characterization results demonstrate that the Cu incorporated MgAl mixed oxides yield good surface area, pore volume and surface basicity benefiting from the fine-tuned Cu molar ratio. Moreover, the incorporation of Cu showed synergistic influence on the surface basic strength distribution, thus potentially affected the catalytic performance of the MgAl (O) mixed oxide. The catalytic performance of the Cu-based mixed oxides in the solvent-free transesterification of glycerol with DMC strongly depends on the amount of strong surface basic density of the catalysts. The MAC-0.6 catalyst exhibited the highest density of strong Lewis basic sites among all synthesised catalysts, consequently, granted the maximum GC yield (91.2%). According to the results procured in this work, a plausible reaction mechanism for the glycerol transesterification over Cu-based mixed oxide catalysts was proposed. Furthermore, the reported mixed oxide catalysts were quite stable in this reaction system and could be efficiently reused for several times without any significant loss in its catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: A series of efficient and robust Cu based mixed oxides were synthesized by a simple co-precipitation method and utilized for the production of glycerol carbonate (GC) via transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC). The synthesized materials were characterized using XRD, UV–vis spectroscopy, SEM, TEM, N2 sorption, CO2-TPD, and XPS. The addition of Cu on Mg/Al mixed oxides exhibits significant changes in its physicochemical properties and catalytic activity. The obtained mixed oxides showed remarkably high transesterification activity towards the efficient conversion of glycerol to GC under economical reaction conditions without using any solvent. Among all the catalysts employed, highest catalytic activity was observed over MAC-0.6 catalyst with glycerol conversion of 96.4% and GC yield of 91.2%. The improved catalytic performance was observed mainly due to the optimized catalyst molar ratio and strong surface basicity. The strong surface basic sites were greatly attributed to the incorporation of Cu2+ cations in the MgAl (O) periclase that efficiently catalyzed the transesterification of glycerol with DMC. Furthermore, the reported catalyst was robust and could be recycled for more than five times without any significant loss in its catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Tuning the basicity of Cu-based mixed oxide catalysts towards the efficient conversion of glycerol to glycerol carbonate
